q: How do I take part in a clinical trial?
a: You can ask your doctor or a patient organisation if they know of any clinical trials that you may be eligible to join. You can also search for information on a number of websites and register your interest in taking part in research.

q: Why join a clinical trial?
a: Clinical trials help doctors understand how to treat a particular illness. It may benefit you, or others like you, in the future. If you take part in a clinical trial, you may be one of the first people to benefit from a new treatment.

q: Will I get paid?
a: Some clinical trials offer payment, while others only cover travel expenses. It's important to find out about the inconvenience and risks involved before you sign up, and to carefully weigh up whether it's worth it.

q: What happens in a clinical trial?
a: All clinical trials of new medicines go through a series of phases to test whether they're safe and whether they work. The medicines will usually be tested against another treatment called a control. Phase 1 trials involve a small number of people, while phase 2 and 3 trials involve larger groups of patients.

q: What should I know before I sign up?
a: Before signing up, it's important to ask questions such as the aim of the trial, the funding, the duration, potential risks and side effects, and what would happen if something went wrong. It's also important to find out about the practical aspects like time commitment, payment, travel costs, and how the treatments may affect you physically and emotionally.

q: How are trials regulated and judged ethical?
a: Before a clinical trial can begin, it needs to be reviewed and authorized by the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA). All medical research involving people in the UK must be approved by an independent research ethics committee to protect the rights and interests of the participants.

q: How are trial results used to improve treatment?
a: Clinical trials can help prevent, detect, diagnose, and treat illnesses. They can also find out how people can control their symptoms or improve their quality of life. The results of clinical trials are sent to regulatory agencies to determine whether new treatments can be marketed and provided through the healthcare system.

q: Where can I find results from trials that are relevant to me?
a: The results of clinical trials are usually published in specialist medical journals and online libraries of evidence. Some well-known examples include The Lancet, British Medical Journal (BMJ), The New England Journal of Medicine, and the Cochrane Library. However, accessing the full articles may require a subscription and they can be difficult to understand.

q: What happens in a clinical trial?
a: All clinical trials of new medicines go through a series of phases to test whether they're safe and whether they work. The medicines will usually be tested against another treatment called a control. Trials often last a year or more and involve several thousand patients.

q: What should I know before I sign up?
a: When you express interest in a trial, a doctor or nurse is likely to tell you something about it in person. You'll also be given some printed information to take away. You may come back with some questions you feel have not been answered.

q: How are trials regulated and judged ethical?
a: Before a clinical trial of a new medicine can begin, a government agency called the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) needs to review and authorize it. The Health Research Authority (HRA) works to protect and promote the interests of patients and the public in health research.

a: Clinical trials can help prevent, detect, diagnose, and treat illnesses. They can also find out how people can control their symptoms or improve their quality of life. a: You can ask your doctor or a patient organization if they know of any clinical trials that you may be eligible to join. You can also search for information on a number of websites and register your interest in taking part in research.

q: What happens in a clinical trial?
a: Clinical trials of new medicines go through phases to test their safety and effectiveness. They usually involve testing the new medicine against either a placebo or a standard treatment already in use. Trials can last a year or more and involve several thousand patients.

q: What should I know before I sign up?
a: Before signing up, you should understand the aim of the trial, how long it will last, what treatment you'll receive, and how the trial may affect you physically and emotionally. You should also consider practical aspects like the time commitment, travel expenses, and possible side effects. Additionally, ask about what support is available and how you'll receive the results.

a: Before a clinical trial can begin, it needs to be reviewed and authorized by the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA). The Health Research Authority (HRA) protects and promotes the interests of patients and the public in health research. All medical research involving people in the UK must be approved by an independent research ethics committee.

q: How are trial results used to improve treatment?
a: Clinical trials help prevent, detect, diagnose, treat, and improve the quality of life for various illnesses. The results of trials are sent to the MHRA, which decides whether to allow the medicine to be marketed. Licensing ensures that a treatment meets certain standards of safety and effectiveness. The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) decides whether the NHS should provide treatments.

q: Where can I find results from trials that are relevant to me?
a: The results of clinical trials are usually published in specialist medical journals and online libraries of evidence. Some well-known examples include The Lancet, British Medical Journal (BMJ), and Cochrane Library. You can use search engines to look for articles and read summaries, but full access may require a subscription. Keep in mind that research papers can be difficult to understand due to medical and scientific terms.
